name: world
description: The world element encapsulates an entire world description including: models, scene, physics, and plugins.

children.name: name
children.description: Unique name of the world

children.name: audio
children.description: Global audio properties.

children.name: device
children.description: Device to use for audio playback. A value of "default" will use the system's default audio device. Otherwise, specify a an audio device file"

children.name: wind
children.description: The wind tag specifies the type and properties of the wind.

children.name: linear_velocity
children.description: Linear velocity of the wind.

children.name: include
children.description: Include resources from a URI. Included resources can only contain one 'model', 'light' or 'actor' element. The URI can point to a directory or a file. If the URI is a directory, it must conform to the model database structure (see /tutorials?tut=composition&cat=specification&#defining-models-in-separate-files).

children.name: merge
children.description: Merge the included model into the top model. Only elements valid in 'world' are allowed in the included model

children.name: uri
children.description: URI to a resource, such as a model

children.name: name
children.description: Override the name of the included entity.

children.name: static
children.description: Override the static value of the included entity.

children.name: placement_frame
children.description: The frame inside the included entity whose pose will be set by the specified pose element. If this element is specified, the pose must be specified.

children.name: model_state
children.description: The model state element encapsulates variables within a model that may change over time, including object poses, the states of its nested models and links and joints, and changes in model scale.

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the model

children.name: model_state
children.description: A nested model state element

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the model.

children.name: scale
children.description: Scale for the 3 dimensions of the model.

children.name: joint_state
children.description: The joint state element encapsulates variables within a joint that may change over time, currently limited to the joint angle.

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the joint

children.name: angle
children.description: Angle of an axis

children.name: axis
children.description: Index of the axis.

children.name: axis_state
children.description: Contains the state of the first joint axis.

children.name: position
children.description: The position of the first joint axis.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If this is a rotational axis and this attribute is true, the joint position is expressed in units of degrees [deg], otherwise it is expressed in radians [rad]. If this axis is translational (such as a prismatic joint), the units will be interpreted in meters [m] regardless of the value of this attribute.

children.name: velocity
children.description: The velocity of the first joint axis.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If this is a rotational axis and this attribute is true, the joint velocity is expressed in units of degrees per second [deg/s], otherwise it is expressed in radians per second [rad/s]. If this axis is translational (such as a prismatic joint), the units will be interpreted in meters per second [m/s] regardless of the value of this attribute.

children.name: acceleration
children.description: The acceleration of the first joint axis.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If this is a rotational axis and this attribute is true, the joint acceleration is expressed in units of degrees per second per second [deg/s^2], otherwise it is expressed in radians per second per second [rad/s^2]. If this axis is translational (such as a prismatic joint), the units will be interpreted in meters per second per second [m/s^2] regardless of the value of this attribute.

children.name: effort
children.description: The effort applied at the first joint axis.

children.name: axis2_state
children.description: Contains the state of the second joint axis.

children.name: position
children.description: The position of the second joint axis.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If this is a rotational axis and this attribute is true, the joint position is expressed in units of degrees [deg], otherwise it is expressed in radians [rad]. If this axis is translational (such as a prismatic joint), the units will be interpreted in meters [m] regardless of the value of this attribute.

children.name: velocity
children.description: The velocity of the second joint axis.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If this is a rotational axis and this attribute is true, the joint velocity is expressed in units of degrees per second [deg/s], otherwise it is expressed in radians per second [rad/s]. If this axis is translational (such as a prismatic joint), the units will be interpreted in meters per second [m/s] regardless of the value of this attribute.

children.name: acceleration
children.description: The acceleration of the second joint axis.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If this is a rotational axis and this attribute is true, the joint acceleration is expressed in units of degrees per second per second [deg/s^2], otherwise it is expressed in radians per second per second [rad/s^2]. If this axis is translational (such as a prismatic joint), the units will be interpreted in meters per second per second [m/s^2] regardless of the value of this attribute.

children.name: effort
children.description: The effort applied at the second joint axis.

children.name: frame
children.description: A frame of reference in which poses may be expressed.

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the frame. It must be unique within its scope (model/world), i.e., it must not match the name of another frame, link, joint, or model within the same scope.

children.name: attached_to
children.description: If specified, this frame is attached to the specified frame. The specified frame must be within the same scope and may be defined implicitly, i.e., the name of any //frame, //model, //joint, or //link within the same scope may be used. If missing, this frame is attached to the containing scope's frame. Within a //world scope this is the implicit world frame, and within a //model scope this is the implicit model frame. A frame moves jointly with the frame it is @attached_to. This is different from //pose/@relative_to. @attached_to defines how the frame is attached to a //link, //model, or //world frame, while //pose/@relative_to defines how the frame's pose is represented numerically. As a result, following the chain of @attached_to attributes must always lead to a //link, //model, //world, or //joint (implicitly attached_to its child //link).

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: link_state
children.description: The link state element encapsulates variables within a link that may change over time, including pose, velocity, acceleration, applied wrench, and the state of attached collisions.

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the link

children.name: angular_velocity
children.description: Angular velocity of the link frame relative to the world frame.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If true, the angular velocity is expressed in units of degrees per second [deg/s], otherwise it is expressed in radians per second [rad/s].

children.name: linear_velocity
children.description: Linear velocity of the link frame relative to the world frame.

children.name: velocity
children.description: Velocity of the link. The x, y, z components of the pose correspond to the linear velocity of the link, and the roll, pitch, yaw components correspond to the angular velocity of the link

children.name: angular_acceleration
children.description: Angular acceleration of the link frame relative to the world frame.

children.name: degrees
children.description: If true, the angular acceleration is expressed in units of degrees per second per second [deg/s^2], otherwise it is expressed in radians per second per second [rad/s^2].

children.name: linear_acceleration
children.description: Linear acceleration of the link frame relative to the world frame.

children.name: acceleration
children.description: Acceleration of the link. The x, y, z components of the pose correspond to the linear acceleration of the link, and the roll, pitch, yaw components correspond to the angular acceleration of the link

children.name: torque
children.description: Torque acting on the link relative to the world frame.

children.name: force
children.description: Force acting on the link at the link frame relative to the world frame.

children.name: wrench
children.description: Force and torque applied to the link. The x, y, z components of the pose correspond to the force applied to the link, and the roll, pitch, yaw components correspond to the torque applied to the link

children.name: collision_state
children.description: Collision state

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the collision

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: plugin
children.description: A plugin is a dynamically loaded chunk of code. It can exist as a child of world, model, and sensor.

children.name: name
children.description: A name for the plugin.

children.name: filename
children.description: Name of the shared library to load. If the filename is not a full path name, the file will be searched for in the configuration paths.

children.name: Elements
children.description: Arbitrary elements and attributes that can be used to configure the plugin

children.name: gravity
children.description: The gravity vector in m/s^2, expressed in a coordinate frame defined by the spherical_coordinates tag.

children.name: magnetic_field
children.description: The magnetic vector in Tesla, expressed in a coordinate frame defined by the spherical_coordinates tag.

children.name: atmosphere
children.description: The atmosphere tag specifies the type and properties of the atmosphere model.

children.name: type
children.description: The type of the atmosphere engine. Current options are adiabatic. Defaults to adiabatic if left unspecified.

children.name: temperature
children.description: Temperature at sea level in kelvins.

children.name: pressure
children.description: Pressure at sea level in pascals.

children.name: temperature_gradient
children.description: Temperature gradient with respect to increasing altitude at sea level in units of K/m.

children.name: projection_type
children.description: Set the type of projection for the camera. Valid values are "perspective" and "orthographic".

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the tracked visual. If no name is provided, the remaining settings will be applied whenever tracking is triggered in the GUI.

children.name: min_dist
children.description: Minimum distance between the camera and the tracked visual. This parameter is only used if static is set to false.

children.name: max_dist
children.description: Maximum distance between the camera and the tracked visual. This parameter is only used if static is set to false.

children.name: static
children.description: If set to true, the position of the camera is fixed relatively to the model or to the world, depending on the value of the use_model_frame element. Otherwise, the position of the camera may vary but the distance between the camera and the model will depend on the value of the min_dist and max_dist elements. In any case, the camera will always follow the model by changing its orientation.

children.name: use_model_frame
children.description: If set to true, the position of the camera is relative to the model reference frame, which means that its position relative to the model will not change. Otherwise, the position of the camera is relative to the world reference frame, which means that its position relative to the world will not change. This parameter is only used if static is set to true.

children.name: xyz
children.description: The position of the camera's reference frame. This parameter is only used if static is set to true. If use_model_frame is set to true, the position is relative to the model reference frame, otherwise it represents world coordinates.

children.name: inherit_yaw
children.description: If set to true, the camera will inherit the yaw rotation of the tracked model. This parameter is only used if static and use_model_frame are set to true.

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: plugin
children.description: A plugin is a dynamically loaded chunk of code. It can exist as a child of world, model, and sensor.

children.name: name
children.description: A name for the plugin.

children.name: filename
children.description: Name of the shared library to load. If the filename is not a full path name, the file will be searched for in the configuration paths.

children.name: Elements
children.description: Arbitrary elements and attributes that can be used to configure the plugin

children.name: physics
children.description: The physics tag specifies the type and properties of the dynamics engine.

children.name: scene
children.description: Specifies the look of the environment.

children.name: light
children.description: The light element describes a light source.

children.name: frame
children.description: A frame of reference in which poses may be expressed.

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the frame. It must be unique within its scope (model/world), i.e., it must not match the name of another frame, link, joint, or model within the same scope.

children.name: attached_to
children.description: If specified, this frame is attached to the specified frame. The specified frame must be within the same scope and may be defined implicitly, i.e., the name of any //frame, //model, //joint, or //link within the same scope may be used. If missing, this frame is attached to the containing scope's frame. Within a //world scope this is the implicit world frame, and within a //model scope this is the implicit model frame. A frame moves jointly with the frame it is @attached_to. This is different from //pose/@relative_to. @attached_to defines how the frame is attached to a //link, //model, or //world frame, while //pose/@relative_to defines how the frame's pose is represented numerically. As a result, following the chain of @attached_to attributes must always lead to a //link, //model, //world, or //joint (implicitly attached_to its child //link).

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: joint
children.description: A joint connects two links with kinematic and dynamic properties. By default, the pose of a joint is expressed in the child link frame.

children.name: model
children.description: The model element defines a complete robot or any other physical object.

children.name: actor
children.description: A special kind of model which can have a scripted motion. This includes both global waypoint type animations and skeleton animations.

children.name: plugin
children.description: A plugin is a dynamically loaded chunk of code. It can exist as a child of world, model, and sensor.

children.name: name
children.description: A name for the plugin.

children.name: filename
children.description: Name of the shared library to load. If the filename is not a full path name, the file will be searched for in the configuration paths.

children.name: Elements
children.description: Arbitrary elements and attributes that can be used to configure the plugin

children.name: name
children.description: Name of the road

children.name: width
children.description: Width of the road

children.name: point
children.description: A series of points that define the path of the road.

children.name: material
children.description: The material of the visual element.

children.name: surface_model
children.description: Name of planetary surface model, used to determine the surface altitude at a given latitude and longitude. The default is an ellipsoid model of the earth based on the WGS-84 standard. It is used in Gazebo's GPS sensor implementation.

children.name: world_frame_orientation
children.description: This field identifies how Gazebo world frame is aligned in Geographical sense. The final Gazebo world frame orientation is obtained by rotating a frame aligned with following notation by the field heading_deg. Options are: - ENU (East-North-Up)

children.name: latitude_deg
children.description: Geodetic latitude at origin of gazebo reference frame, specified in units of degrees.

children.name: longitude_deg
children.description: Longitude at origin of gazebo reference frame, specified in units of degrees.

children.name: elevation
children.description: Elevation of origin of gazebo reference frame, specified in meters.

children.name: surface_axis_equatorial
children.description: Equatorial axis of a custom surface type, specified in meters. This is only required for custom surfaces.

children.name: surface_axis_polar
children.description: Polar axis of a custom surface type, specified in meters. This is only required for custom surfaces.

children.name: heading_deg
children.description: Heading offset of gazebo reference frame, measured as angle between Gazebo world frame and the world_frame_orientation type. The direction of rotation follows the right-hand rule, so a positive angle indicates clockwise rotation (from east to north) when viewed from top-down. Note that this is not consistent with compass heading convention. The angle is specified in degrees.

children.name: state
children.description: The state element encapsulates variables within a world that may change over time, including object poses, dynamic states such as velocity and acceleration, a description of objects added to the world, and a list of objects deleted from the world.

children.name: population
children.description: The population element defines how and where a set of models will be automatically populated in Gazebo.

children.name: name
children.description: A unique name for the population. This name must not match another population in the world.

children.name: model_count
children.description: The number of models to place.

children.name: distribution
children.description: Specifies the type of object distribution and its optional parameters.

children.name: type
children.description: Define how the objects will be placed in the specified region. - random: Models placed at random. - uniform: Models approximately placed in a 2D grid pattern with control over the number of objects. - grid: Models evenly placed in a 2D grid pattern. The number of objects is not explicitly specified, it is based on the number of rows and columns of the grid. - linear-x: Models evently placed in a row along the global x-axis. - linear-y: Models evently placed in a row along the global y-axis. - linear-z: Models evently placed in a row along the global z-axis.

children.name: rows
children.description: Number of rows in the grid.

children.name: cols
children.description: Number of columns in the grid.

children.name: step
children.description: Distance between elements of the grid.

children.name: box
children.description: Box shape

children.name: size
children.description: The three side lengths of the box. The origin of the box is in its geometric center (inside the center of the box).

children.name: cylinder
children.description: Cylinder shape

children.name: radius
children.description: Radius of the cylinder

children.name: length
children.description: Length of the cylinder along the z axis

children.name: pose
children.description: A pose (translation, rotation) expressed in the frame named by @relative_to. The first three components (x, y, z) represent the position of the element's origin (in the @relative_to frame). The rotation component represents the orientation of the element as either a sequence of Euler rotations (r, p, y), see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=specify_pose, or as a quaternion (x, y, z, w), where w is the real component.

children.name: relative_to
children.description: If specified, this pose is expressed in the named frame. The named frame must be declared within the same scope (world/model) as the element that has its pose specified by this tag. If missing, the pose is expressed in the frame of the parent XML element of the element that contains the pose. For exceptions to this rule and more details on the default behavior, see http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics. Note that @relative_to merely affects an element's initial pose and does not affect the element's dynamic movement thereafter. New in v1.8: @relative_to may use frames of nested scopes. In this case, the frame is specified using `::` as delimiter to define the scope of the frame, e.g. `nested_model_A::nested_model_B::awesome_frame`.

children.name: rotation_format
children.description: 'euler_rpy' by default. Supported rotation formats are 'euler_rpy', Euler angles representation in roll, pitch, yaw. The pose is expected to have 6 values. 'quat_xyzw', Quaternion representation in x, y, z, w. The pose is expected to have 7 values.

children.name: degrees
children.description: Whether or not the euler angles are in degrees, otherwise they will be interpreted as radians by default.

children.name: model
children.description: The model element defines a complete robot or any other physical object.
